title-group.article-title: Bacterial LPS Differently Modulates Inflammasome Gene Expression and IL-1β Secretion in Trophoblast Cells, Decidual Stromal Cells, and Decidual Endothelial Cells

article-meta.aff: 1Laboratory of Medical Investigation in Dermatology and Immunodeficiency, Faculty of Medicine, University of Sao Paulo, Sao Paulo, Brazil
2Institute for Maternal and Child Health–IRCCS “Burlo Garofolo,” Trieste, Italy
3Department of Life Sciences, University of Trieste, Trieste, Italy
4Institute for Maternal and Child Health, IRCCS, Burlo Garofolo, and University of Trieste, Trieste, Italy

author-notes.corresp: Alessandra Pontillo, Laboratory of Medical Investigation in Dermatology and Immunodeficiency, LIM-56, Faculty of Medicine, University of Sao Paulo, Sao Paulo, Brazil. Email: pontillo.a@gmail.com

abstract.p: Three Nod-like receptors (NLR family, pyrin domain containing 1/NLRP1, NLR family, pyrin domain containing 3/NLRP3, NLR family, CARD domain containing 4/NLRC4) and the adaptor molecule PYD and CARD domain containing protein/PYCARD are involved in the assembling of multiprotein complexes known as inflammasomes, leading to caspase 1 activation and consequent interleukin (IL)-1β secretion. Considering that inflammasomes are involved in sensing pathogens and in triggering inflammatory and immune response, we hypothesized that they could also act in the placenta as an efficient innate mechanism during pregnancy infections. For this reason the activation of inflammasome was tested in 3 human placental cell populations in the presence of a common gram-negative compound (lipopolysaccharide [LPS]). The transcription of NLRP1, NLRP3, NLRC4, PYCARD, CASP1, and IL1B genes and the secretion of IL-1β were evaluated in human first trimester cytotrophoblasts (CTBs), decidual stromal cells (DSCs), and endothelial cells (DECs) stimulated with LPS. In CTBs and DSCs, LPS induced an augmented expression of CASP1 and IL1B and the specific upregulation of NLRP3 within the 3 NLRs tested. Moreover, LPS induced secretion of IL-1β from CTBs and DSCs. These results suggest the involvement of NLRP3 inflammasome in the placental innate response. The LPS did not affect inflammasome gene transcription and IL-1β production in DECs. Bacterial LPS enhances NLRP3 inflammasome components in trophoblast and DSCs, suggesting that this innate immune complex could play a key role in placental immune defense.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Placenta acts as immunological maternal–fetal barrier where trophoblast recognizes microbes through pattern recognition receptors (PRRs). Nod-like receptors (NLRs), a cytoplasmic family of PRRs, have been described in the placenta, suggesting a role in innate immune response regulation against infections.1 Three NLR proteins (NALP1/NLRP1, NALP3/NLRP3, IPAF/NLRC4) and the adaptor molecule ASC/PYCARD are involved in the assembling of multiprotein complexes known as inflammasomes, leading to caspase 1 activation and consequent interleukin (IL)-1β secretion.2

Activation of the NLRP1 and NLRC4 inflammasomes is promoted by specific pathogenic stimuli, such as muramyldipeptide (MDP) and flagellin, while the NLRP3 inflammasome is activated in response to a number of physically and chemically diverse triggers. Among these are endogenous stress signals, such as extracellular adenosine triphosphate (ATP) or uric acid crystals, exogenous particulates like alumen and asbestos, as well as pathogens (bacteria, virus, fungus, protozoa).2 The tissue distribution of the 3 receptors varies,3–5 and in this way NLRs and the relative inflammasomes contribute to the host defense throughout the body. Inflammasomes contribute to innate immunity and response against pathogens through IL-1β secretion but also through additional mechanisms such as the induction of pyroptotic cell death, the restriction of bacterial replication, and the activation of lipid metabolic pathways for cell repair.6 Defects in inflammasome activation lead to constitutive IL-1β secretion, excessive inflammation, and tissue damage 6

Elevated caspase 1 activity and IL-1β concentration were observed in pregnancy infections, suggesting the involvement of inflammasomes in triggering inflammatory response within the placenta.1 Furthermore, dysregulation in inflammasome activity could contribute to placental dysfunction resulting in adverse obstetrical outcomes.

Starting from the current knowledge about NLRs and placenta,1 we hypothesized that inflammasome could be involved in the placental response against pathogens, in particular gram-negative bacterial infection during pregnancy. For this purpose, human primary first-trimester cytotrophoblast cells (CTB), decidual endothelial cells (DECs) and decidual stromal cells (DSCs) were stimulated with bacterial lipopolysaccharide (LPS) and the expression of inflammasome components and IL-1β secretion was evaluated.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: The CTBs, DECs, and DSCs were isolated from 8 first trimester placentas after obtaining written informed consent from the participants. The CTBs, DECs and DSCs were purified from placental specimens as described previously.7–9 Briefly, CTBs were isolated by negative CD45 selection (immunomagnetic beads, Dynal, Invitrogen, Life Technologies, Carlsbad, California) to avoid leukocytes contamination (Supplementary Figure 1), cultivated overnight on 5 µg/cm2 fibronectin (FN, Roche, Germany), then detached by trypsin treatment and cultured in RPMI-1640 with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS). The DECs were isolated by positive selection with Dynabeads M-450 (Dynal, Invitrogen) coated with Ulex europaeus 1 lectin (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, Missouri) and cultivated on 5 µg/cm2 FN in human endothelial serum free medium (Gibco, Invitrogen) with 20 ng/mL basic fibroblast growth factor (bFGF), 10 ng/mL epidermal growth factor (EGF), and 10% FBS. The DSCs were obtained by culturing the DEC-negative cell fraction in RPMI-10% FBS.9 Primary cultures of DECs and DSCs between the second and sixth passage were used. The CTBs, DECs, and DSCs were stimulated with 0.5 µg/mL ultrapure LPS (0111:B4 strain; Invitrogen), for 4 and 24 hours.7–9 Supernatants were collected for IL-1β measurement and the cells were lysed for RNA extraction. The Bioethical Committee of IRCCS “Burlo Garofolo” (Trieste, Italy) approved the study (RC14/08).

RNA was isolated with RNAqueous micro kit (Ambion, Life Technologies, Austin, Texas) and retro-transcribed with MuLV Reverse Transcriptase (Applied Biosystems/AB, Life Technologies, Carlsbad, California). The genes NLRP1, NLRP3, NLRC4, PYCARD, CASP1, and IL1B were amplified with TaqMan Gene Expression Assays (AB) using the ABI 7900 HT platform (AB). The ACTB was the housekeeping gene (AB) used for normalization. Relative quantitative expression10 was calculated as 2−ΔΔCt. The secretion of IL-1β was evaluated with enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA; Pierce Biotecnology, Rockford, Illinois).

One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was used to compare the gene expression. t Test was used to compare IL-1β secretion. Prism 5.01 software (GraphPad Software) was used for graphs and statistical analysis.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: We evaluated NLRP1, NLRP3, NLRC4, PYCARD, CASP1, and IL1B gene expression in CTBs, DECs, and DSCs stimulated with 0.5 µg/mL LPS for 4 and 24 hours. The modulation of mRNA levels by LPS in these cell populations was evaluated according to Livak,10 comparing stimulated cells with resting ones. Results obtained from 8 independent experiments were summarized in Figure 1 (A-C), and data were entirely reported in Supplementary Data 1.

caption.p: Inflammasome genes expression and IL-1β secretion in cytotrophoblast cells (CTB), decidual cells (DECs), and decidual stromal cells (DSCs) stimulated with lipopolysaccharide (LPS). Messenger RNA (mRNA) expression levels in CTBs (A), DECs (B), and DSCs (C) at 4 (white bars) and 24 (black bars) hours after stimulation with 0.5 µg/mL LPS was reported for NLRP1, NLRP3, NLRC4, PYCARD, CASP1, and IL1B genes. Expression levels of each gene were calculated with respect to the unstimulated condition (R) as 2−ΔΔCt, where ΔΔCt = ΔCt LPS − ΔCt R. Results are expressed as the mean of 2−ΔΔCt ± standard error, n = 8. All the Ct values were normalized against ACTB Ct (ΔCt). 1-way analysis of variance (ANOVA)s and Bonferroni posttest were used to compare the nod-like receptors ([NLRs] NLRP1, NLRP3, and NLRC4) mRNA levels as well as data obtained for each gene at 4 and 24 hours. *P < .05. The IL-1β concentration (pg/mL) was reported for R and LPS conditions (D). t test was used to compare R and LPS conditions in each cell type. *P < .05.

sec.p: After 4 hours LPS induced a 2-fold NLRP3 and 40-fold IL1B increased expression in CTBs with respect to untreated CTBs (Figure 1A). This NLRP3 messenger RNA (mRNA) expression was significantly higher when compared with NLRP1 and NLRC4 (P = .0009). The LPS did not modify the expression of other inflammasome genes. At 24 hours, LPS upregulated NLRP3 and IL1B expression but scarcely modulated the expression of other genes (Figure 1A). The differential expression among NLRs at 24 hours did was not significantly different (P = .2126). Levels of inflammasome genes in LPS-CTB significantly varied between 4 and 24 hours of LPS stimulation (P < .0001; Supplementary Data 1).
When the LPS effect was evaluated in DECs, none of the genes was significantly modulated at 4 hours as well as at 24 hours; moreover, NLRC4 expression was not detected (Figure 1B).

In LPS-induced DSCs (LPS-DSC), NLRP3 expression was augmented (3 folds) with respect to the resting DSC at 4 and 24 hours. After 24 hours, LPS augmented NLRC4 expression 2-fold with respect to resting DSCs, while it did not affect NLRP1 expression. The NLRP3 level was higher than NLRP1 and NLRC4 in LPS-DSC at 4 and 24 hours, even if only values at 4 hours were significantly different (P = .0001). Gene expression among the 3 NLRs did not significantly vary in LPS-DSC at 24 hours (P = .2146). In DSCs, PYCARD and CASP1 were poorly modulated by LPS at 4 hours but induced at 24 hours (2- and 3-fold, respectively). The LPS enhanced IL1B expression in DSCs especially at 4 hours (Figure 1C). In DSCs, the expression of inflammasome genes did not significantly vary between 4 and 24 hours of LPS stimulation (P = .0559; Figure 1C and Supplementary Data 1).

To assess whether the 3 types of placental cells respond differently to LPS, inflammasome gene expression was compared among CTBs, DECs, and DSCs. The levels of NLRP3 and IL1B were statistically higher in CTBs and DSCs compared to DECs at 4 hours and at 24 hours (P < .0001). Secretion of IL-1β was evaluated as the marker of inflammasome activation in CTB, DEC, and DSC supernatants after 24 hours of LPS stimulation. Undetectable levels of cytokine were found after 4 hours of stimulation. Unstimulated resting cells at time 0, 4 and 24 hours showed similar low concentration of IL-1β, and for this reason comparison were made at the same time (24 hours). The LPS induced high IL-1β secretion in CTBs (P = .002) and DSCs (P = .001) but not in DECs (P = .877; Figure 1D).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our results support recent findings about the expression of inflammasome components in trophoblast cells1 and show for the first time this expression in DSCs. We evidenced that recognition through NLRs and consequent inflammasome activation could act specifically in human cytotrophoblast cells and in DSCs and not in other placental cells such as DECs, indicating that within placenta different cellular components could play different role in the fetal–maternal interface.

Endothelial cells act together with leukocytes during inflammation and response against pathogens, and the presence of NLRP3 inflammasome in endothelial cells has been reported previously,11 however DEC could behave atypically as shown in the expression of other innate immune proteins, such as C1q.7

Bacterial LPS enhanced expression of inflammasome components and induced IL-1β secretion in trophoblasts and in DSCs but not in DEC, emphasizing that CTBs and DSCs actively participate to innate immune response through NLRs and inflammasome biology. In particular, NLRP3 expression was upregulated in CTBs and DSCs when compared to other NLRs genes NLRP1 and NLRC4, suggesting that NLRP3 could be the intracellular receptor involved in placental innate response against gram-negative bacteria. The LPS strongly induced IL1B transcription and IL-1β secretion, confirming the activation of caspase 1. Taking into account that NLRP3 expression is a limiting factor for inflammasome assembling12–13and that the expression of NLRs and inflammasomes is generally inducible and not constitutive,5 these data let us assume that an increased expression of NLRP3, CASP1, and IL1B together with the secretion of IL-1β are suggestive of the assembling and activation of NLRP3 inflammasome. However we cannot exclude that other pathways could be involved in the placental response against LPS such as TLR4.14

Mulla et al15 showed that uric acid was able to induce inflammasome activation in first-trimester trophoblast cell line Sw.71. Since uric acid specifically activates NLRP3= inflammasome,2 our findings, obtained using LPS, reinforce the role of NLRP3 inflammasome in placental immune response.

Noteworthy, the entity of LPS-induced NLRP3 inflammasome expression in CTB is far from the one reported in innate immune cells,16 supporting the idea that trophoblast is the main actor in innate immune defense, but it could also work as inflammasome response modulator to prevent excessive inflammation affecting pregnancy outcome. However, IL1B elevated expression in CTB tells us another story: probably in the trophoblast inflammasome is not the only pathway responsible for IL1B induction.

Similarly, the expression of NLRP3 inflammasome components observed in DSCs suggests a major role of this complex in the biology of stromal cells. Moreover, considering the pivotal function of NLRP3 inflammasome in the dendritic cell biology,2 these data reinforced the previously reported categorization of DSC as nonprofessional antigen presenting cells.17

Our results support previous findings about the presence of NLR and inflammasome in human trophoblasts, evidencing that within placental decidua, stromal cells express NLRP3 inflammasome, whereas the endothelial cells do not, suggesting distinct immunologic functions among different placental subpopulations.

In conclusion, the NLRP3 inflammasome plays a role in the placental immune response against gram-negative bacteria and in the modulation of antimicrobial defense at maternal–fetal interface. Different to other inflammasomes, NLRP3 inflammasome is able to sense a lot of pathogen compounds as well as endogenous danger molecules2 and represent an excellent defense platform in this context. These findings open new scenarios of actors and mechanisms involved in placental immunity, where the role of each component and cell should be studied in depth. Moreover, considering the risk of an inappropriate inflammatory reaction during pregnancy, the modulation of inflammasome activation could represent, in the future, an alternative therapeutic approach.
